VIA E-FILING

Re: In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
Evidence of Notice of the January 10, 2025 Public Hearing 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
 
Dear Mr. Seuffert and Judge McKenzie: 
 
Per paragraph 2 in the Administrative Law Judge’s December 31, 2024 Third 
Hearing Order in the above referenced Docket, Minnesota Power hereby submits 
electronic copies of notices provided by Minnesota Power and the Minnesota Public 
Utilities Commission (Commission) relating to the January 10, 2025 public hearing. 
Minnesota Power and Commission staff communicated on December 10, 2024 regarding 
plans to provide notice to customers on the Company’s website and social media 
platforms.  
The Commission posted information including the Webex link on its website and 
calendar on December 27, 2024. A copy of the calendar event is attached herein. 
Minnesota Power also posted notices of the January 10, 2025 meeting to its website’s 
homepage, Facebook, and X. An electronic copy of the notices are attached herein.  
 If you have any questions regarding this filing, please contact me at (651) 592-
8312 or mbrodin@allete.com .  
 
Sincerely, 
 
/s/ Matthew R. Brodin   
 
       Matthew R. Brodin 
ALLETE Senior Attorney

STATE OF MINNESOTA  
OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS  
FOR THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  THIRD  PREHEARING ORDER  
This matter  is pending before Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.  
Based upon the record, the prehearing conference, and the parties’ stipulations,  
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED:  
1. A virtual public hearing in this matter is currently scheduled for January 10, 
2025,  at 10:00 a.m.  via WebEx. Instructions for joining the meeting as follows:  
 Join by Internet : 
WebEx (webinar) Link:   https://minnesota.webex.com/   
Webinar Number: 2486 577 0547  
Webinar Password: MPHearing!  
 Join by Phone:  
Dial: 1 -855-282-6330 (Toll Free)  
Access Code:  2486 577 0547  
 2. As soon as possible the parties shall file evidence of proper notice of the 
January 10, 2025 public hearing.  
 3. Additional public hearings will be held the week of April 7, 2025. The parties 
shall provide the Administrative Law Judge will a proposed schedule for the hearings with locations and times no later than February 3, 2025. The parties must file an affidavit of publication or other evidence of proper notice of the additional public hearings no later than two weeks prior to the first hearing date.  
 
4. At the start of the public hearings , the Administrative Law Judge will give a 
short introduction. This will be followed by presentations by Commission staff, the 
Applicant, and any intervenors  each explaining their roles  and the proposed transaction.  
 
[214603/1]  2 
 
5. Following these introductions, the public hearings will open for comments 
and questions by the public. There will be a sign- up sheet available at in-person hearings 
and a similar virtual process . Members of the public who wish to speak will be required to 
sign up on the sign- up sheet. Members of the public will be called in the order that they 
sign up on the sign- up sheet. Depending on the number of individuals who wish to speak, 
the Judge may pl ace a time limit on speakers. Members of the public will be reminded 
that they may submit written comments as exhibits into the hearing record, or file 
comments with the Commission.  
 
6. Public hearings will adjourn with the last speaker, even if it is prior to the 
stated hearing end time. Therefore, members of the public who wish to speak should 
arrive at the beginning of the public hearing and put their names on the sign- up sheet. To 
the extent practicable, the public hearings will end at the stated end time, but may be 
extended, depending on the number of individuals wishing to provide comment.  
 Date d: December 31, 2024

Minnesota Power provides this filing to update the Minnesota Public Utilities 
Commission (“Commission”) on the recent Federal Energy Regulatory Commission 
(“FERC”) approval of the transaction with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and

approved the Acquisition.  Enclosed is the  FERC Order approving the Acquisition, 
which  was filed  in FERC Docket No. EC24 -105-000.

I. Background  
A. Description of Applicants  
1. ALLETE a nd its Affiliates  
3. Applicants state that ALLETE is a publicly traded energy services company 
headquartered in Duluth, Minnesota.  Applicants state that  ALLETE’s regulated public 
utility operations include:  its operating division Minnesota Power; its wholly  owned 
subsidiary Superior Water, Light and  Power Company (SWL&P); and, through ALLETE 
Enterprises, Inc. (ALLETE Enterprises), an approximately 8 % interest in American 
Transmission Company, LLC (ATC), a  Wisconsin -based regulated utility that owns and 
maintains electric transmission assets, the  operational control over which has been 
transferred to the Midcontinent Independent System  Operator, Inc. (MISO).  Applicants 
state that ALLETE’s unregulated public utility generation activities include those of its 
merchant generator public utility subsidiaries that it indirectly owns through its wholly owned subsidiaries ALLETE Enterprises and ALLETE Clean Energy, Inc. (ALLETE Clean Energy).
4 
a. Minnesota Power  
4. Applicants state that ALLETE, through Minnesota Power:  (i ) generates, 
transmits, and distributes electricity in northern Minnesota; (ii) provides regulated utility electric service to retail customers and electric generation and transmission service to municipal customers as well as to its wholly owned subsidiary SWL&P; and (iii) owns 
electric  transmission and distribution lines and substations.  Applicants state that 
Minnesota Power controls approximately 2,476 megawatts (MW) of electric generation 
capacity through its  ownership of generation facilities and as a buyer under third -party 
power purchase agreements.  Applicants represent that Minnesota Power is authorized by 
the Commission to make  wholesale sales of electric power, capacity, and ancillary 
services at market -based rates .  Applicants state that Minnesota Power’s retail operations

B. Description of the Proposed Transaction  
23. Applicants state that pursuant to the Proposed Transaction, Mer ger Sub will merge 
with and into ALLETE, with ALLETE as the surviving entity.  Upon consummation of 
the Proposed Transaction, Buyer will directly own ALLETE, and Buyer will be owned 
and controlled 40 % by a wholly owned subsidiary of Canadian Pension Plan Investments 
and 60 % by investment funds or vehicles managed by affiliates of  Global Infrastructure 
Management .  Applicants explain that the jurisdictional facilities affected by the 
Proposed Transaction consist of:  (i) ALLETE’s  market -based rate  tariff and any related 
agree ments; (ii) Minnesota Power’s cost -based rate schedules and any  related 
agreements; (iii) Minnesota Power’s and SWL&P’s transmission facilities and transmission formula rate and any related agreements under the MISO t ariff, including  
grandfathered transmission agreements identified in Attachment P of the MISO t ariff;  
(iv) ALLETE Clean Energy’s market -based rate tariff and any related agreements; (v) the 
ALLETE Clean  Energy public utility subsidiaries’ market -based rate tariffs and any 
related agreements; (vi) the  ALLETE Enterprises public utility subsidiaries’ market -
based rate  tariffs and any related agreements; (vii) the  interconnection facilities 
associated with the electric generation facilities owned by Minnesota  Power, the 
ALLETE Clean Energy public ut ility subsidiaries, and the ALLETE Enterprises public  
utility subsidiaries; and (viii) various books and records.
40

B. Substantive Matters  
1. FPA Section 203 Standard of Review  
29. FPA section 203(a)(4) requires the Commission to approve proposed dispositions, 
consolidations, acquisitions, or changes in control if the Commission  determines that the 
proposed transaction will be consistent with the public interest.43  The Commission’s 
analysis of whether a  proposed transaction is consistent with the public interest generally 
involves consideration of three factors:  (1) the effect on competition; (2) the effect on 
rates; and (3) the effect on regulation.44  FPA section 203(a)(4) also requires the 
Commission to find that the proposed transaction “will not result in cross -subsidization of 
a non -utility associate company or the pledge or encumbrance of utility assets for the 
benefit of an associate company, unless the Commission determines that the cross -
subsidization, pledge, or encumbrance will be consistent with the public interest.”45  The 
Commission’s regulations establish verification and informational requirements for entities that seek a determination that a proposed transaction will not result in 
inappropriate cross -subsidization or pledge or encumbrance of utility assets.
46

ii. Commission Determination  
37. In analyzing whether a proposed transaction presents vertical market power 
concerns, the Commission considers the vertical combination of upstream inputs, such as transmission or natural gas, with downstream generating capacity.  As the Commission has previously found, transactions that combine electric generation assets with inputs to 
generating power (such as natural gas, transmission, or fuel) can harm competition if the 
transaction increases an entity’s ability or incentive to exercise vertical market power in wholesale electricity markets.  For example, by denying rival entities access to input s or 
by raising their input costs, an entity created by a transaction could impede entry of new competitors or inhibit existing competitors’ ability to undercut an attempted price increase in the downstream wholesale electricity market.

under its b lanket authorization and the active interests i n ALLETE that Global 
Infrastructure Management (and, therefore, BlackRock) will hold as a result of the 
Proposed Transaction because both will not exist at the same time.  Applicants further 
assert that BlackRock’s various non-controlling investments in utility securities under its 
blanket authorization are not relevant to the  Commission’s analysis of the Proposed 
Transaction.  Applicants state that the  Commission has explained  that the utilities whose 
securities are held by an investor (e.g., BlackRock) under such a blanket authorization are 
not controlled by the investor, and that the Commission has routinely authorized 
transactions involving the acquisition of active interests in public utilities under FPA 
section 203 without requiring examination of investments held pursuant to a blanket 
authorization .93 
61. In the November 12 Answer, Applicants assert that the Commission should reject 
Joint Protestors ’ irrelevant and unsupported request to hold the Application in abeyance 
until the Commission has completed its review of the BlackRock  Reauthorization 
Application.  Applicants argue that Joint Protestors have had ample opportunity to raise 
any concerns related to the Application in this proceeding , where they have made 
multiple filings, which Applicants have answered .94  
iii. Commission Determination  
62. We decline to delay action in this proceeding  until the Commission  completes its 
review of if or how the BlackRock Transaction  and the Proposed Transaction  materially 
change the facts of BlackRock’s blanket authorization, as requested by Joint Protestors.  We decline to reassess BlackRock’s blanket authorization  in this proceeding because 
questions about the conditions applicable to  BlackRock’s  blanket authorization are 
beyond the scope of this proceeding.  Concerns about the conditions applicable to a 
specific applicant’s blanket authorization , the applicant’s  holdings associated with its 
blanket authorization, and whether and how separate transactions impac t the blanket 
authorization  may be raised in a proceeding where that applicant files for authorization or 
reauthorization of a blanket authorization.  We note that the BlackRock Reauthorization 
Application is pending before the Commission . 
63. As to BlackRock’s specific holdings in ALLETE , we agree that BlackRock will 
no longer hold indirect, non -controlling interests in ALLETE under its blanket 
authorization following close of the Proposed Transaction .  The Proposed Transaction 
will result in ALLETE changing from a publicly traded company to a privately held 
 
93 Id. at 4 -5. 
94 November 12 Answer at 2 -3. 
Docket No. EC24- 105-000 - 27 - 
company, held  by Canadian Pension Plan Investments and G lobal Infrastructure 
Management , the latter of which is owned entirely  by BlackRock.95   
3. Other Considerations  
64. Information and/or systems connected to the B ulk Power S ystem involved in this 
transaction may be subject to reliability and cybersecurity standards approved by the 
Commission pursuant to FPA section 215.96  Compliance with these standards is 
mandatory and  enforceable regardless of the physical location of the affiliates or 
investors, information database, and operating systems.  If affiliates, personnel or investors are not authorized for access to such information and/or systems connected to the Bulk Power System, a public utility is obligated to take the appropriate measures to 
deny access to this information and/or the equipment/software connected to the B ulk 
Power System.  The mechanisms that deny access to information, procedures, software, 
equipment, etc., must comply with all applicable reliability and cybersecurity standards. 
The Commission, North America n Electric Reliability Corporation , or the relevant 
regional entity may audit compliance with reliability and cybersecurity standards. 
65. FPA section 3 01(c) gives the Commission authority to examine the books and 
records of any person who controls, directly or indirectly, a jurisdictional public utility 
insofar as the books and records relate to transactions with or the business of such public utility.
97  The approval of the Proposed Transaction is based on such examination ability.  
In addition, applicants subject to Public Utility Holding Company Act of 2005  (PUHCA 
2005 )98 are subject to the record -keeping and books and records requirements of PUHCA 
2005.  
66. Section 35.42 of the Commission’s regulations  requires that sellers with market -
based rate authority timely report to the Commission any change in status that would reflect a departure from the characteristics the Commission relied upon in gran ting 
 
95 See October 2 Answer at 4 -5; see also Glob. Infrastructure Mgmt. , LLC ,        
188 FERC ¶ 61,166 at P 57 (finding that  after the BlackRock Transaction, Clearway  
Energy Group LLC  securities that BlackRock previously reported under the blanket 
authorization “will no longer be covered by the blanket authorization and instead will 
reflect BlackRock’s controlling interest in Clearway.  This same treatment would apply 
to other securities BlackRock holds under its blanket authorization if BlackRock later 
seeks to acquire entities that themselves hold amounts of the same securities.”). 
96 16 U.S.C. § 824o.

market -based rate authority.99  To the extent that a transaction authorized under FPA 
section 203 results in a change in status, sellers that have market -based rates are advised 
that they must comply with the requirements of section 35.42 . 
67. With respect to App licants’ hydroelectric generating stations, the authorization in 
this proceeding is made under FPA section 203 and is not an authorization for the 
licensee to transfer its license or any rights thereunder granted , including property rights 
that are  necessary to operate and maintain the project s.  The licensee is prohibited from 
selling, leasing, transferring, abandoning, or otherwise disposing of the project , including 
all project property  covered by the license, until Commission authorization is al so 
received pursuant to Part 9 of the Commission’s regulations,100 and as required by 
standard Article 5 of the license.101  The authorization in this proceeding under FPA 
section 203 does not prejudge the Commission’s determination on an application for approval to transfer a license or to voluntarily sell, lease, transfer, abandon, or otherwise 
dispose of project  property . 
The Commission orders : 
 
(A) The Proposed Transaction is hereby authorized, as discussed in the body of 
this order.   
 
(B) Applicants are directed to submit an informational filing within 10 days of 
each state commission’s approval of potential ring -fencing provisions, as discussed in the 
body of this order.  
 
(C) Applicants must inform the Commission of any material change in 
circumstances that departs from the facts or representations that the Commission relied upon in authorizing the Proposed Transaction within 30 days from the date of the  
material change in circumstances .   
 
(D) The foregoing authorization is without prejudice to the authority  of the 
Commission or any other regulatory  body with respect to rates, service, accounts, 
valuation, estimates or determinations of costs, or any other matter whatsoever now 
pending or which  may come before the Commission.  
 
(E) Nothing in this order shall be construed to imply acquiescence in any 
estimate or determination of cost or any valuation of property claimed or asserted.

(G) Applicants sh all make any appropriate filings under section 205 of the FPA,

(H) Applicants shall notify the Commission within 10 days of the date on which 
the Proposed Transaction is consummated.  
 
(I) If Applicants seek to recover transaction -related costs through their 
transmission or wholesale requirements rates, they must make a new FPA section 205

are exceeded by the saving s produced by the Proposed Transaction.

required to follow the Commission’s Uniform System of Accounts, then the Applicants shall submit their final accounting entries within six months of the date that the
